category: Life Scenarios — Money, Family, Friendship, Addiction

units.core_reframe: The fear of not having enough money is rarely about money — it's about what money represents: safety, worth, or proof that you made it.
question_bank: What does having money protect you from feeling about yourself?
When did financial security first feel like a measure of your worth?
What would 'enough' actually feel like — not look like, feel like?
What are you really trying to secure when you think about money?
units.short_reframe: The scarcity isn't in the account — it's in the story running underneath it.
units.short_question: What does money mean to you beyond what it can buy?
units.rewire_target: Separate financial reality from identity — money as a tool, not a verdict.

units.core_reframe: Using money as a measure of success is measuring with someone else's ruler — the number only feels meaningful in comparison to another number.
question_bank: Whose financial life are you unconsciously benchmarking against?
If no one knew how much you earned, would the amount still matter as much?
What would you do with money if it carried no social signal whatsoever?
What does earning more solve that earning less doesn't — specifically?
units.short_reframe: The number only has power because of the comparison it enables.
units.short_question: Whose scoreboard are you actually playing on?
units.rewire_target: Disentangle financial goals from social comparison — build intrinsic financial values.

units.core_reframe: Spending that doesn't reflect your values is almost always spending that is trying to create a feeling — not acquire a thing.
question_bank: What were you feeling in the hour before the purchase?
What does the thing you bought represent — not what it does, what it represents?
What feeling were you trying to install, and how long did it last?
What would you have had to sit with if you hadn't bought it?
units.short_reframe: The purchase was solving an emotion, not a need.
units.short_question: What were you actually trying to feel when you bought it?
units.rewire_target: Build awareness of emotional spending — distinguish acquisition from emotional regulation.

units.core_reframe: The inability to say no to financial requests from family often has nothing to do with money — it has to do with what saying no means about who you are.
question_bank: What do you believe happens to the relationship if you say no?
Is the giving coming from love, or from fear of what happens if you don't?
What would you need to believe about yourself to hold this boundary?
Whose voice do you hear when you feel guilty for keeping your own money?
units.short_reframe: The guilt isn't about money — it's about the cost of being seen as someone who says no.
units.short_question: What are you buying with the yes that you can't afford?
units.rewire_target: Separate generosity from self-erasure — give from fullness, not from fear.

units.core_reframe: The role you were assigned in your family — the responsible one, the peacemaker, the difficult one — was a survival strategy, not a personality.
question_bank: What role were you cast in your family — and who cast you in it?
What happens in the family system when you step outside that role?
How much of who you are today was designed to function inside that family?
What parts of yourself didn't fit the role and got quietly set aside?
units.short_reframe: The role you play in your family was assigned before you could choose.
units.short_question: Who were you before the family needed you to be something specific?
units.rewire_target: Separate family-assigned identity from chosen self — recover suppressed dimensions.

units.core_reframe: The adult who still lives for parental approval is still a child in one specific room of themselves — the one that never got told it was enough.
question_bank: What would you do differently tomorrow if their approval was permanently unavailable?
What have you built, chosen, or avoided because of how they would see it?
At what age did you decide their approval was the measure of your worth?
What would it mean to finally stop waiting for the verdict?
units.short_reframe: The approval you're still seeking was never fully given — and waiting hasn't changed that.
units.short_question: What would you do if their opinion simply stopped reaching you?
units.rewire_target: Transition from external parental validation to internal self-authorization.

units.core_reframe: Most of your deepest beliefs about money, love, success, and self-worth were installed before you were old enough to question them.
question_bank: What belief about yourself have you never actually examined — you just received it?
What did your family teach you about yourself without ever saying it directly?
Which of your values are genuinely yours, and which are borrowed?
What would you believe about yourself if you had grown up in a completely different family?
units.short_reframe: The beliefs running your life were written before you could read.
units.short_question: Which belief about yourself did you choose, and which were you handed?
units.rewire_target: Develop examined beliefs — distinguish inherited programming from chosen values.

units.core_reframe: The one who always shows up for everyone else often never learned that showing up for themselves is also an option.
question_bank: When did you decide that your needs come last in this family?
What are you afraid would happen to the family system if you stopped holding it together?
Is the caretaking coming from love — or from fear of what you'd feel if you stopped?
What do you need right now that you would never ask for?
units.short_reframe: The one who holds everyone else together rarely asks who is holding them.
units.short_question: What do you need that you've never allowed yourself to ask for?
units.rewire_target: Build reciprocal care — recognizing own needs as legitimate without guilt.

units.core_reframe: Choosing distance from family can be an act of self-preservation — and still carry guilt, grief, and doubt simultaneously. These aren't contradictions. They're the cost.
question_bank: What are you grieving about this distance that you haven't fully acknowledged?
Is the guilt telling you that you did something wrong — or that you love someone you had to move away from?
What did you need from this relationship that it was never able to give?
What would you lose if you fully accepted that this was the right choice?
units.short_reframe: You can make the right choice and still grieve it completely.
units.short_question: What are you mourning underneath the relief?
units.rewire_target: Hold complexity of difficult family decisions — right and painful can coexist.

units.core_reframe: Exhaustion after social interaction is often the cost of performing a version of yourself rather than inhabiting one.
question_bank: Which version of yourself shows up in this friendship — and how close is it to the actual one?
What would you say or do differently if you weren't managing how they see you?
What part of yourself do you keep off the table with this person?
What are you afraid they'd think if they saw the unedited version?
units.short_reframe: The exhaustion after being with people is often the cost of the performance, not the company.
units.short_question: What would you say if you weren't managing their impression of you?
units.rewire_target: Move from performed friendship to inhabited presence — authenticity over approval.

units.core_reframe: A friendship where one person always gives and the other always receives isn't a friendship — it's a dynamic both people agreed to, usually without speaking.
question_bank: When did you decide that giving more than you receive is just how this relationship works?
What would change if you simply gave the same amount they give — no more?
What do you get from being the one who gives more?
Have you ever directly asked for what you need in this friendship?
units.short_reframe: The imbalance continued because both people let it — including you.
units.short_question: What do you get from being the one who gives more?
units.rewire_target: Develop reciprocity awareness — recognize patterns of over-giving and the needs they serve.

units.core_reframe: Friendships that drift aren't always failures — sometimes they're both people becoming who they actually are, and those people fit differently.
question_bank: Is this friendship ending, or evolving into something your current self doesn't need in the same way?
What did this friendship give you that you're afraid you won't find elsewhere?
What version of yourself existed in this friendship that you may have outgrown?
What are you grieving — the person, or who you were when you were close?
units.short_reframe: Growing apart is sometimes two people growing — just in different directions.
units.short_question: Are you grieving the person, or who you were when you were close?
units.rewire_target: Normalize friendship evolution — distinguish ending from transformation.

units.core_reframe: Jealousy of a friend's success is painful precisely because it lives at the intersection of love and longing — you want what they have and you want them to have it.
question_bank: Is the feeling jealousy — or is it a signal about something you want that you haven't admitted?
What specifically do they have that you want — the thing itself, or what it represents?
What would it mean about your friendship if you were genuinely happy for them?
What does their success make you afraid about your own path?
units.short_reframe: Jealousy of someone you love is information about yourself wearing someone else's face.
units.short_question: What is their success pointing to that you want but haven't named?
units.rewire_target: Transform jealousy into self-knowledge — use envy as directional data.

units.core_reframe: Every addiction began as a solution — something that worked, at least for a while, to make an unbearable feeling bearable.
question_bank: What feeling does it reliably make go away — even temporarily?
When you imagine not having it available, what's the first feeling that arrives?
What was happening in your life when this became a pattern rather than an occasional choice?
What problem was it originally solving that you still haven't found another way to solve?
units.short_reframe: It became a habit because it worked — the question is what it was working on.
units.short_question: What feeling does it make disappear that you haven't found another way to face?
units.rewire_target: Humanize the addiction — understand the unmet need beneath the behavior.

units.core_reframe: The shame after relapse often produces more of the behavior it condemns — because shame is exactly the feeling the behavior was managing in the first place.
question_bank: What does relapsing mean to you about who you are — not what you did, but who you are?
Is the self-punishment helping — or is it the thing that makes the next episode more likely?
What would self-compassion look like here — not excusing it, but not destroying yourself over it?
What were the conditions in the days before — what was building up?
units.short_reframe: The shame after the relapse feeds the next one — it's the same fuel.
units.short_question: What were you carrying in the days before that you hadn't put down?
units.rewire_target: Break shame-relapse cycle — build self-compassionate accountability instead.

units.core_reframe: The ability to function despite something is not the same as the thing not being a problem — it just means your threshold for normal has shifted.
question_bank: What would someone who loves you say about this if they were being completely honest?
What are you comparing yourself to in order to conclude it's not that bad?
What has it quietly cost you that you don't include in the calculation?
What would life look like if this pattern simply wasn't part of it?
units.short_reframe: Still functioning doesn't mean the cost isn't being paid — just that the bill hasn't arrived yet.
units.short_question: What has it quietly cost you that you leave out of the calculation?
units.rewire_target: Dissolve functional denial — honest accounting of actual costs beyond performance.

units.core_reframe: When a behavior has been present long enough, it starts to feel like a personality — not something you do, but something you are. The fear of quitting becomes the fear of not knowing who's left.
question_bank: Who were you before this became a consistent part of your life?
What would you do with the time, the money, the emotional space if it weren't there?
What parts of your social life or identity are built around it?
Who do you think you'd be without it — and is that person more frightening or more free?
units.short_reframe: The fear of stopping is often the fear of meeting whoever is underneath.
units.short_question: Who are you afraid you'd find if this weren't there to fill the space?
units.rewire_target: Separate behavior from identity — develop a self-concept not dependent on the pattern.
